TEXT: The application was lodged with the ORG by a mother , PERSON , on behalf of herself and her CARDINAL children PERSON , PERSON , PERSON and PERSON . PERSON , born in DATE , is a NORP national . Her CARDINAL children were born in DATE , DATE and DATE and are NORP and NORP nationals . Ms GPE currently lives in GPE , GPE , while the children ’s whereabouts are unknown .
The respondent Government are represented by their Agent , Mrs A. ORG , PERSON , of ORG .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
This application is closely related to application no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , declared inadmissible by ORG on DATE .
That application had been lodged by Ms GPE on behalf of her CARDINAL children . ORG left open the question as to whether PERSON had to be regarded as an applicant in her own right .

PERSON , a NORP national , had been married to a NORP national , Mr O. , with whom she has CARDINAL children ( PERSON , PERSON and PERSON ) . She has another daughter by a first marriage ( PERSON ) . After having left Mr O. in DATE , ORG ( GPE ) granted PERSON sole custody of PERSON , PERSON and PERSON , while Mr O. was granted access . The court ordered Ms GPE not to remove the children from GPE , unless Mr O. consented to it . In DATE Ms GPE and the applicants travelled to GPE for a DATE stay after having obtained Mr O. ’s consent . However , they did not return to GPE after DATE had lapsed . PERSON filed a petition for divorce in GPE and requested the sole custody of PERSON , PERSON and PERSON . However , ORG then granted Mr O. the children ’s sole custody . On DATE the Zweibrücken ORG ( GPE ) rejected Mr O. ’s request to return PERSON , PERSON and PERSON under LAW on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction ( “ LAW ” ) . On DATE the ORG revoked that decision and ordered Ms Paradis to return the children to Mr O. On DATE ORG refused to admit the complaint lodged by Ms Paradis on behalf of PERSON , PERSON and PERSON .

On DATE ORG ordered the court bailiff to execute ORG decision of DATE . However , on DATE his attempts failed due to the applicants’ explicit refusal . On DATE the ORG vested the court bailiff with the right to use force against the applicants .
On DATE ORG refused to admit the ORG complaint .
On DATE the ORG found that there was no violation of the applicants’ rights under LAW and declared the application inadmissible as being manifestly ill - founded .

On DATE the court bailiff again tried in vain to execute ORG decision of DATE . PERSON declared that she had already brought the children to GPE DATE and refused to disclose their whereabouts . On CARDINAL DATE ORG ordered PERSON coercive detention ( ORG ) according to section QUANTITY on Non - Contentious Proceedings ( Gesetz über die Angelegenheiten der freiwilligen PERSON ) in order to obtain the children ’s whereabouts ( see “ Relevant domestic law ” below ) . It elaborated that ORG had already decided in DATE that the children should be returned to PERSON and that any further delay in executing this decision had to be avoided . The court furthermore found that the other coercive measure under LAW of LAW , a penalty payment , would not prove to be successful . Under those circumstances the court concluded that LOC detention was proportionate , but clarified that she would be released immediately once the children were returned . It furthermore held that due to the urgent nature of the case it had not been called for to hear PERSON in advance . In this respect the court also pointed out that it had expected Ms GPE to thwart her coercive detention .
On DATE ORG rejected the ORG complaint and confirmed the lower court ’s reasoning .
On DATE ORG refused to admit Ms LAW complaint .
The applicant PERSON was detained for DATE from DATE to DATE . She did not disclose the children ’s whereabouts and they appear to be still in hiding .

“ ( CARDINAL ) If somebody is obliged by court order to carry out an action which merely depends on his will , to omit an action or to tolerate an action , the court may , unless the law provides differently , impose a penalty payment in order to ensure the compliance with its order . If a person has to be returned , the court may order coercive detention independently from the penalty payment . ...

( CARDINAL ) .... Coercive detention ( section CARDINAL ) shall be announced , unless the execution of the court order is particularly urgent or if it has to be expected that the execution of coercive detention will be thwarted . ... Sections CARDINAL , CARDINAL to CARDINAL , CARDINAL § CARDINAL and CARDINAL and sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the Civil Procedure Law Code apply accordingly to the execution of coercive detention . ... ”
“ The detention may not exceed DATE . After the completion of DATE the obligor ( Schuldner ) is to be released ex officio . “
